background: The use of face masks during the COVID-19 pandemic is recommended by governments as a way to prevent the spread of the virus. Face masks serve a dual purpose: they can prevent infected individuals from passing on the virus to others (source control) and also provide protection to healthy individuals from getting infected (prevention). background: Small-scale observational studies indicate that masks, including cloth face masks and surgical masks (medical masks), have been effective in reducing the community spread of COVID-19. However, clinical evidence on their efficacy in COVID-19 transmission is still limited and subject to ongoing scientific debate. A WHO-funded systematic review highlighted that using face masks, particularly N95 respirators, can significantly reduce the risk of infection with beta coronaviruses. Additionally, a scientific review emphasized the importance of factors like product design and fabrication techniques in determining the overall efficacy of face masks.
